etymologies: mid 16th century (gradually superseding late Middle English frequence; originally denoting a gathering of people): from Latin frequentia, from frequens, frequent- ‘crowded, frequent’

definitions: the rate at which something occurs or is repeated over a particular period of time or in a given sample

examples.text: shops have closed with increasing frequency during the period

definitions: the fact of being frequent or happening often.
the ratio of the number of actual to possible occurrences of an event.
shortDefinitions: ratio of number of actual to possible occurrences of event

definitions: the (relative) number of times something occurs in a given sample.
shortDefinitions: relative number of times something occurs in given sample

definitions: the rate at which a vibration occurs that constitutes a wave, either in a material (as in sound waves), or in an electromagnetic field (as in radio waves and light), usually measured per second

examples.text: different thicknesses of glass will absorb different frequencies of sound

shortDefinitions: rate of vibration which constitutes wave

definitions: the particular waveband at which a radio station or other system broadcasts or transmits signals

examples.text: a radio station on a single AM radio frequency
a coding sequence to ensure that everyone changes frequency in the correct manner
